His wife, Fanny, had a most unfeeling heart, and in joining her he became no friend to the family of his father. He told his mother, however, that he would do every thing in his power; and for the credit of the promise, and for the sake of the good connection, and under the influence of his more feeling sisters, and the memory of his father's partiality, he did in reality exert himself to fulfil it. But he had not the strength of resolution, nor the disinterestedness to give him a decisive superiority over the sollicitations of his wife and her mother. He allowed himself to be persuaded to think differently; common sense was spoken to little, and he could not resist the persistent urgency of Mrs. John Dashwood, who, with her daughter, had lived on the excessive friendship of the late owner of Norland, and whose expectations had been answered by almost daily presents. She considered the marriage as what must very materially affect her own and her daughter's situation in life; and, under the double fear of sinking into obscurity and poverty, and of losing at once her home and her hopes, she worked incessantly on her husband's feelings, reprobating his intentions in every possible light, and continually representing the high respectability and settled comforts of her own situation, as of a nature that ought not, and could not be sacrificed. She talked to him of the danger of disinheriting his only son; of the impropriety, or rather indecency, as she expressed it, of his intending to place any part of his own fortune in the hands of a man whom he had not brought up, and who was not by nature and education entitled to such a preference; and she urged, that if he made over any thing to his sisters, he ought to be quite sure that they would have no further occasion for his help, which she hinted might be very soon the case, if Mr. Willoughby's expectations were to be realised. In an evil hour he yielded to her wishes; instead of the thousand pounds which he had contemplated as the assistance to be given to each of his sisters, he declared it to be his intention to settle on Mrs. John Dashwood only the sum of three hundred pounds, recommending her to use it for the advantage of her other sisters, if she thought fit.

His mind was not of the sort that opens itself at once to a fair statement; he saw only the advantage of making Haydon Park entirely his own, and the propriety of his doing everything in his power to increase the fortune of his own children. The good sense and information of Henry Dashwood were no match for the cunning of Mrs. John Dashwood and the force of prejudice in her husband. They persuaded him that the fortune, which he was so eager to leave to his daughters, was really his own, and that he had a right to be governed by his own inclinations in its disposal. They worked on his fears of want in his old age, and his solicitude for the welfare of his children; and these were feelings which especially touched, because they pretended to be considering what was for the advantage of his children. In an evil hour they succeeded; he acted so unwisely as to cut off the young ladies from the fortune which, in the event of his dying soon, their mother had hoped to make largely available for their happier establishment in life. By an addition to the large sum already in his own hands, and by his marrying a woman of fortune, it might have been in his power to have done much good; and from the happy union of their tempers, there seemed to be every prospect of his doing considerable good. But this was a sacrifice which he was not disposed to make; and ten thousand pounds, instead of being added to the nine or ten thousand that already belonged to them, were lost to them for ever. The avarice and injustice of John and his wife left them in a state of the most distressed poverty; and their mother, who for many years had been afflicted with a decline, sank under the double weight of disappointment and wretchedness.

en_second_half: indefatigable in her inquiries for a suitable dwelling in the neighbourhood of Norland; for to remove far from that beloved spot was impossible. But she could hear of no situation that at once answered her notions of comfort and ease, and suited the prudence of her eldest daughter, whose steadier judgment rejected several houses as too large for their income, which her mother would have approved.

en_results_raw: she longed for a change of scene, which she hoped might contribute to the recovery of her peace. But the removal was delayed by various circumstances. The house was not easily disposed of, and the little money which their father had left them was hardly sufficient for their immediate wants. Their two eldest sons were settled in life, and though, from inclination and affection, they might have been expected to do a great deal, they could do nothing which was not for their own advantage. The partiality of Sir John Middleton, however, who was of opinion that the estate should be left to his wife's family, and who had always been of great use to them, and particularly to Elinor, was a considerable resource. He could tell them of a house which had long been to let, which he understood was neither dear nor inconvenient, and which would therefore be quite suitable for them. It was in the neighbourhood of his own estate, among the ancient trees of the park, in a situation which he thought likely to be pleasing to them, and he could undertake to get them a good settlement there, if they would apply to him. This was doing a great deal more than he had ever done for any body before; but he loved Mrs. Dashwood, and his conscience told him that he could not do enough for her. They talked the matter over, consulted every body, and it was determined to be a most desirable place; and though no promises were given by any of the Miss Steeles, who had been consulted among the rest, of their going to Barton, or paying it the least visit, there was every prospect of their being in the neighbourhood, and this was a great recommendation of the place. The whole was talked over so warmly by Sir John and his mother, that it was impossible for Mrs. Dashwood to do less than resolve to accept the offer immediately, and her resolution was carried into execution with the greatest despatch. The house was taken, the promise made, and they were engaged to be at Barton Park by Michaelmas. The removal was performed in the beginning of September, and the Dashwoods were in general well satisfied with their new abode. The house was large and handsome, and their situation, though not in the centre of the village, was still in sight of the church, and within convenient distance of it; a circumstance which recommended it very much to Mrs. Dashwood, whose time was too much employed to allow of her being always on horseback when she paid her devotions at Barton parish church. The furniture of the house had been well chosen; the rooms were large and light, and in every respect comfortable; and when they had arranged everything to their own liking, they could not but feel that they had nothing to wish for in situation or accommodation. The park was a great advantage; it was not so heavily wooded as to exclude the sun, nor so open as to be devoid of shade; and besides the plantations, there was a quantity of pleasant greensward.

en_results_raw: for Mr. Rushworth, which Maria immediately seized, and began to read. "Oh! here is a letter from Sotherton," said she, looking up with a smile; "and it is a long one too. I wonder what news there can be from Sotherton." She then resumed her reading, and the others were silent, till she had finished the letter, which was from Mrs. Grant, and contained an account of her visit to Sotherton, and the party there; with some compliments to the young ladies, and an invitation for them all to come and see her. "Well," said Maria, as soon as she had done, "I do not wonder at their wishing to get rid of us. We were very dull, I dare say, last week. But I am sure I do not want to go. It would be such a trouble to get ready, and then it is just the time of year when one does not care to stir out of doors. I wonder what my father will say." "Oh! I am sure he will be delighted," cried Fanny, "to have so pleasant a party to invite. It will be a great pleasure to him, and I hope we shall go." "I am sure we shall not," replied Maria, decidedly. "I know my father. He is always so reasonable. He will consider what weather we are likely to have at this time of year, and what fatigue it would be to get ready, and he will not wish to accept the invitation." "But, Maria," said Edmund, "do you not think it would be rather ungracious to decline such an invitation, after having been so much obliged to Mrs. Grant and her family?" "Ungracious! Nonsense! Why should it be ungracious? We cannot help having colds and coughs, and no one is to blame. I am sure Mrs. Grant will not think us ungracious, however we may choose to act." "I hope not," said Edmund, "but I suspect she will. She is very goodnatured, and not used to such behaviour." "Well," cried Maria, impatiently, "I am sure I do not want to go, and I will not go, and that is enough. I hate running about from place to place, in all weathers, for nothing but the pleasure of other people. I am sure it is slavery, and I will not be a slave." "I am sure you are very good-natured, Maria," said Fanny, "to talk of such a sacrifice for our sakes; but I hope we shall go. It would be a pleasure to me beyond anything." "Oh! you always will have your fancies," replied Maria, rather crossly; "but I hope mine will prevail with my father this time." "I do not think," said Edmund, "that your fancy of staying at home will have much difficulty in prevailing with you, for I doubt whether we shall receive any invitation." "Nonsense!" cried Maria; "why should not Mr. Rushworth ask us? He is always civil enough to us all." "But," said Edmund, "do you not think it possible that he may consider it rather troublesome to be troubled with so large a party as ours?" "No; I am sure he will ask us. He will not find us troublesome. We are very well-behaved children, I assure you." "I hope so," said Edmund, smiling, "for your sake, not for Mr. Rushworth's." "Well," cried Maria, impatiently, "we will not talk any longer about it. I am sure I do not want to go, and I will not go, and that is enough." She then turned the conversation, and they soon after rose from breakfast.

Elinor sabía que Edward tenía un corazón bueno y que su amor por Lucy era auténtico, pero el hecho de que Lucy viniera de una familia con tal reputación le causaba inquietud. La posibilidad de que Lucy traiga problemas económicos o una mala reputación a través de su familia podía arruinar no solo a Edward, sino también a las aspiraciones de Elinor para él. Elinor se preguntaba cómo podría abordar este tema delicado con Edward sin lastimar sus sentimientos ni romper su confianza. Debía encontrar una manera de expresar sus preocupaciones de manera empática y comprensiva, asegurándose de que Edward entendiera que su amor por él era incondicional, pero que también tenía responsabilidades hacia su propio futuro y el de su familia. en_results: of their engagement. It is evident that his affection for Marianne was sincere, though transient; and had he not been so warmly attached to her, he
en_results_raw: of their engagement. It is evident that his affection for Marianne was sincere, though transient; and had he not been so warmly attached to her, he would never have engaged himself. But his affection, though warm, was light and easily changed. He was too selfish to be constant to any but himself; and as soon as he could see another object, more to his personal advantage, in marriage with Miss Grey, he did not scruple to sacrifice the first. His sense of honour, or what he fancied such, operated only in public; in private, he had no check. It was his wish to be thought a man of honour, but it was not his practice; and while he was applauded by the world which never looked beneath the surface, his own conscience reproached him. His affection for Marianne, though it had been real, was no proof of his principle, since it had been so much the creature of the moment, and so little the result of that firm and well-established regard for her which alone could secure her happiness in marriage. His behaviour to her, in withdrawing his affection, was marked with a mean disregard of her feelings, which showed him to be wholly unsuitable for the man who could be relied on for another's ultimate good. It is a dangerous kind of affection, very commonly felt, which takes delight in possessing but does not consider how it is to be retained; and when love, or even serious regard, is thus rooted in selfishness, its excesses are not merely mischievous, they are despicable. Willoughby's love for Marianne was of this description; and had it lasted, would have been one of those evil alliances which make domestic misery. His change of sentiment, therefore, though it brought pain to others, was a benefit to Marianne; and while it disgraced himself, it saved her from attaching her happiness to a man whose character would have rendered him quite unworthy of it. His subsequent behaviour, in endeavouring to conceal his marriage, was a further proof of his selfishness and folly; but it is to be hoped that the consciousness of having acted so meanly may operate as a check on his future conduct, and that he may yet be taught to feel the value of a well-regulated mind and a steady character.

She found herself lost in memories, each melody a bridge to moments shared with Willoughby. The music, once a source of joy, now served as a vessel for her sorrow. She played with a fervor that betrayed her inner turmoil, each chord struck with a heaviness that matched the weight in her heart. The songs they had sung together seemed to linger in the air, a ghostly duet that only she could hear. Her eyes, brimming with unshed tears, traced the familiar lines of the sheet music before her, each note a reminder of his absence. The room, once filled with the warmth of their companionship, now felt cold and empty. She continued to play, each piece a tribute to the love she had lost, a bittersweet symphony of longing and regret. As the night deepened, so did her despair, until finally, exhausted and spent, she let the final chord fade into silence. The silence that followed was deafening, a stark contrast to the music that had filled the room moments before. It was in this quietude that she allowed herself to fully feel the depth of her loss, the void left by Willoughby's departure. The evening had been a cathartic release, a necessary surrender to the pain that had been building within her. As she sat there, amidst the stillness, she knew that healing would be a long and arduous journey, but it was one she would have to undertake. The music, once a source of shared happiness, now stood as a testament to the love she had known and the heartache that followed its end. And with a heavy heart, she resolved to face the days ahead, one note at a time.

en_results_raw: conversation proceeded, it became increasingly clear that Elinor's confidence was as much a part of her charm as her fortune. She continued, "Without them, as the saying goes, we would be like ships without sails, adrift in the vast sea of society. My wealth opens doors, but it is my competence that allows me to navigate the rooms beyond with grace and purpose. Similarly, your competence, Edward, is a treasure in itself, a key that unlocks opportunities. Wealth can be squandered, but true competence, like a well-honed skill, only sharpens with time. It is the foundation upon which one builds a life of meaning and achievement. I admire that in you, just as I value my own resources. Together, we could complement each other in ways that transcend mere material wealth. It is not just about what we have, but how we use it, and in that regard, I believe we are not so different after all." Elinor's words hung in the air, a testament to her insight and the depth of her character. Edward, touched by her perspective, found himself reevaluating his own worth, realizing that competence could indeed be as valuable as wealth, if not more so.

en_results_raw: continuing to think about how much it costs to live comfortably these days. The price of essentials like food, housing, and education has risen significantly over the years. While two thousand a year might have been considered sufficient in the past, today it would be quite a challenge to support a family on such an income. The cost of living has increased dramatically, necessitating a higher income to cover all necessary expenses. Moreover, the concept of 'moderate income' is highly subjective and varies greatly depending on geographical location, lifestyle choices, and the number of dependents. In urban areas, for instance, the cost of living is significantly higher than in rural regions, making it even more difficult to manage on a modest income. Additionally, unexpected expenses such as medical bills or home repairs can quickly deplete savings, further emphasizing the need for a more substantial financial cushion. Therefore, while Marianne might consider two thousand a year to be moderate, in contemporary terms, it would likely be seen as quite limited, requiring careful budgeting and perhaps even financial assistance to make ends meet.

I hope you can see the distinction and understand my perspective better. en_results_raw: that she is always in spirits, and never low but by some very strong reason? She is not an ill-humoured girl, as Marianne will sometimes fancy; nor is she disposed to unhappiness. She has a lively, playful disposition, which exercise of her talents only serves to brighten. With her musical abilities, she is sure of her own consequence; and I really do not see any danger of her being made unhappy by a refusal which, however she may joke about it, she does not herself expect." Edward looked at her with a smile, and said, "You are very kind, Miss Dashwood, in your representations of your sister; and I dare say you are perfectly correct in your opinion. But though Lucy's disposition may be all you describe, and though I have no reason to expect a refusal, still the offer of marriage is a serious business, and not to be concluded without some anxiety." Elinor felt a glow of gratitude towards him for this speech; it was so exactly what was proper, so free from the presumption which might have been expected under the circumstances, that she could have wished Marianne to hear it, as a lesson of what was due on such occasions to the feelings of others. "I am very far from undervaluing the importance of the step," she replied, "or from knowing that it ought not to be entered on without serious reflection. But Lucy's lively spirits and sanguine temper lead me to hope that she will recover her good humour very soon, and that a little time will convince her that she is not really unhappy."

en_results_raw: do not like to see the evidences of neglect and decay. I like to see a well-kept garden, a well-tended wood, a well-managed estate. It is not the mere beauty of nature that pleases me, but the hand of man improving, adorning, and preserving that beauty. I am not a poet, Charlotte, nor a philosopher; I am a practical man, and I look at things from a practical point of view. The picturesque, to me, is often the unpicturesque; it is the untidy, the overgrown, the neglected. I would rather see a straight avenue of noble trees, well-trimmed hedges, and a carefully maintained lawn than the wildest, most rugged scenery untouched by human care. It is not the absence of cultivation that I admire, but its presence, its evidence of human industry and taste. Therefore, while I appreciate your love for the wild and the untamed, I must confess that my own preference leans towards the cultivated and the cared-for. This is not a matter of the heart, Charlotte, but of taste and inclination. I hope you can understand and respect my perspective, as I do yours.

en_results_raw: had always been remarkably consistent in her manners. Her politeness was as unvarying as the ticking of a clock, and it was this very predictability that made her so valued in social circles. She never raised her voice, never lost her temper, and never failed to address everyone with the same level of respect, regardless of their status or behavior. Her children often joked that she could smile through a storm, and indeed, her composure was legendary. This unwavering civility extended to her interactions with the staff at the local church where she volunteered, the neighbors who sometimes fell short of her high standards, and even the less fortunate whom she visited regularly. Her dedication to maintaining a polite demeanor was not just a personal preference but a deeply ingrained principle, a testament to her upbringing and the values she held dear. I am sorry—but I cannot." "Not well enough!" cried he, "nonsense! You look as well as possible. You must come—you shall come. I will not take no for an answer. You must not disappoint them. You must not think of such a thing. Come, come, it is all settled. I will call for you at half-past three. Depend upon it, you will find yourself ever so much better by that time. You must not give way to little trifling ailments. Come, you must not." Harriet, in spite of her illness, felt a glow of pleasure at his earnestness and urgency; but she was obliged to be firm, and with many thanks and much embarrassment, again declined. Mr. Elton was not to be beaten. "I am determined to have you," said he; "I will not go without you. You shall be drove in my curricle. You shall be as comfortable as possible; and I will take such excellent care of you! I am only afraid of your refusing again when I come for you. Do not keep me waiting more than five minutes, I pray, or I may be tempted to say something rash." With this he was gone; and Harriet, left to consider and reconsider the point alone, found it a harder question than she could have supposed. She was really not very well; but then, to be going out in Mr. Elton's curricle, with Mr. Elton's promise to take such excellent care of her—there was something so inviting in the very idea, so against all her former expectations—so like a turn in fortune's wheel which she could never have anticipated. She was in a state of great doubt and anxiety; and it was full half a minute to the appointed time, ere she had finally resolved to let him come for her.

en_results_raw: and a general disinclination to every sort of employment which might rouse her from her languor. She was often fatigued, and often wished for solitude; but she never mentioned her sister's name without feelings of kindness and affection. Edward, on his side, was not less changed. His spirits seemed to have sunk into a state of listless indifference, which nothing seemed able to rouse. He was often absent from the breakfast table, and when present, was silent and abstracted. His father observed these symptoms, and though he did not take much notice of them, yet he mentioned to Mrs. Dashwood, one day, that he was afraid Edward was not very well. "He looks pensive and low," said he; "I do not like to see him so much alone. He should ride more; and when the weather is like this, a chaise–drive might do him good. But he is not gay. I could almost wish to see him more of his own age. Young people should amuse themselves more than he does." Mrs. Dashwood felt that there was something wrong, though she could not tell what, and her anxiety for him increased. She wished her husband would press the matter a little farther; but he had no penetration; and Edward's character, though amiable, was not open; and when he chose to be reserved, could conceal from any one but his mother the state of his mind. She talked to him herself, endeavoured to engage him in conversation, to draw out his opinions and feelings; but in vain. She could get nothing from him. He listened to her with complacency, answered her with sweetness, but told her nothing. en_first_half: "His character is now before you; expensive, dissipated, and worse than both. Knowing all this, as I have now known it many weeks, guess what I must have felt on seeing your sister as fond of him as ever, and on being assured that she was to marry him: guess what I must have felt for all your sakes. When I came to you last week and found you alone, I came determined to know the truth; though irresolute what to do when it WAS known. My behaviour must have seemed strange to you then; but now you will comprehend it. To suffer you all to be so deceived; to see your sister—but what could I do? I had no hope of interfering with success; and sometimes I thought your sister's influence might yet reclaim him. But now, after such dishonorable usage, who can tell what were his designs on her. Whatever they may have been, however, she may now, and hereafter doubtless WILL turn with gratitude towards her own condition, when she compares it with that of
en_second_half: my poor Eliza, when she considers the wretched and hopeless situation of this poor girl, and pictures her to herself, with an affection for him so strong, still as strong as her own, and with a mind tormented by self–reproach, which must attend her through life. Surely this comparison must have its use with her. She will feel her own sufferings to be nothing. They proceed from no misconduct, and can bring no disgrace. On the contrary, every friend must be made still more her friend by them. Concern for her unhappiness, and respect for her fortitude under it, must strengthen every attachment. Use your own discretion, however, in communicating to her what I have told you. You must know best what will be its effect; but had I not seriously, and from my heart believed it might be of service, might lessen her regrets, I would not have suffered myself to trouble you with this account of my family afflictions, with a recital which may seem to have been intended to raise myself at the expense of others."

Marianne continued to ponder the situation, her brow furrowed in deep thought. The more she considered Mrs. Ferrars' behavior, the more perplexed she became. It was unlike anything she had experienced before. Normally, when someone took a dislike to another, it was evident in their actions, their avoidance, their coldness. Yet, here was Mrs. Ferrars, seemingly warm and welcoming, engaging in conversation and showing genuine interest. This contradiction puzzled Marianne to no end. She tried to rationalize it, considering every possible explanation. Perhaps Mrs. Ferrars was simply a very complex individual, capable of harboring contradictory feelings. Maybe she found Marianne's straightforwardness refreshing, a rare trait in the society circles she frequented. Or, could it be that Mrs. Ferrars saw something in Marianne that others did not, a potential that she wished to nurture, despite the social barriers? The possibilities seemed endless, each more intriguing than the last. Marianne's mind raced with these thoughts, each one more speculative than the last. The once vibrant colors of the landscape seemed to fade into a monochrome backdrop, a silent witness to her internal turmoil. Her daily excursions had ceased to be a source of joy or distraction; they were simply a part of her existence now, a routine she followed without much thought or enthusiasm. Marianne's indifference to whether she went out or stayed in was a symptom of a deeper disconnection from her own desires and feelings. She was adrift, her life a series of automatic actions devoid of passion or purpose. This state of apathy was a stark contrast to the vibrant, opinionated woman she once was, and it troubled her, though she struggled to articulate her concerns even to herself. The question of why she felt so unmoved by activities that once brought her pleasure lingered in her mind, a silent query that she couldn't shake off. "I cannot conceive," said Edward, "how a person can have leisure to be rational, and yet not feel some curiosity on the subject of his own amusement. To me, a day would be wasted, a journey would be lost, if I did not make it a means of acquiring knowledge." "You are speaking now," said Elinor, "to one who agrees with you entirely; but we are not all formed alike. There are some people whose powers would be quite thrown away, if they were not, in some degree, forced into action. There are some whose faculties are only sharpened by necessity; who do not know the worth of what they have, till they are in danger of losing it. And there are others, of still less active minds, who, if they were not roused by some external circumstance, would pass through the world utterly without improvement or enjoyment."

La recuperación de tal dolor requiere tiempo, dolor, y quizás incluso la aceptación de que tal perdida nunca será completamente olvidada. Además, el valor de algo no se mide solo por su reemplazabilidad; a menudo, es la emoción y la conexión personales las que hacen invaluables. Por lo tanto, la respuesta a la pérdida de algo tan especial como un amor profundo no es simplemente encontrar algo similar o igual de valioso; es más compleja y personal que eso. The dismissal was not just a simple act of anger or disappointment; it was a deliberate severance, a finality that echoed through the halls of the grand estate like a funeral bell. Edward had always been his mother's favorite, the golden child whose every action was met with approval and whose future seemed as bright as the morning sun. Yet, in a moment of misunderstanding or perhaps a clash of wills, everything changed. His mother, a woman of formidable presence and unyielding principles, had decided that Edward's actions were unforgivable. The reasons behind this unhappy rupture were shrouded in mystery, known only to the two parties involved. Edward, now cast out, found himself adrift, his identity and sense of belonging torn asunder. As he walked away from the house, the once familiar walls seemed to close in around him, suffocating him with their memories. His future, once bright with promise, now stretched out before him like a vast, uncertain wilderness. Edward knew that this was not just a temporary falling out; it was a permanent severance, a chasm that could never be bridged. The pain of his mother's rejection cut deep, a wound that would take a long time to heal, if it ever did. As he disappeared into the distance, the echoes of his mother's words followed him, a haunting refrain that would haunt his every step. This was not just a loss; it was a profound and tragic transformation in Edward's life, one that would shape his destiny in ways he could not yet foresee.

She could not help feeling disappointed; she had been looking forward to his staying longer, to his being more communicative, to his giving her some more information about Willoughby. She was sorry to see him go, and could not help suspecting that his abrupt departure was owing to some wish of secrecy or avoidance. "I am sorry to part with you so soon," said she, "and I cannot say how much obliged I am to you for your kindness to Marianne." "My dear madam," replied the Colonel, with a bow, "it only remains for me to assure you of my continuance in the same good wishes for your family which have already engaged me. I shall be happy to be of service whenever I can. Adieu." With these words, he was gone, and Mrs. Jennings, turning to Marianne, observed, "Well, my dear, I thought he would never go. I am sure he is a very polite man." Marianne made no answer, and her mother continued, "And such a particular attention to you too! I wonder what he means by it. I am sure it is very kind of him." Marianne's thoughts were far away; she was dwelling on the idea of Willoughby's engagement, and her countenance expressed such gloom, such abstraction, as made her mother uneasy. "Well, my dear," said she, "do not look so sorrowful. Colonel Brandon is a very agreeable man, I assure you, and I am sure he means to be our friend." Marianne, roused from her reverie, only answered, "I am sure I do not know what you are talking about." "Why, about Colonel Brandon, to be sure," cried her mother. "You heard what he said just now." "Yes, I heard," replied Marianne, "but it signified nothing." "Nothing!" repeated her mother, in great astonishment. "Nothing! Why, he was as civil to you as possible." "Civil!" repeated Marianne, with strong disgust. "Yes, civil. And pray, what more would you have?" "I do not know what I wish," said Marianne, impatiently; "but I know very well what I do not wish, and that is civility of the kind." "Dear me!" cried her mother, "what a strange girl you are, to be sure! Why, you are not satisfied with being noticed and attended to by a very agreeable man, who is rich and has such good manners! What can you want?" Marianne made no answer, and her mother continued, "I declare, my dear, I am at a loss to understand you. You are the most unaccountable creature in the world. I am sure I cannot guess what you mean." Marianne was silent; and her mother, after a short pause, added, "But come, my dear, let us go in; I am sure you are tired, and I have a great deal to tell you." They entered the house, and Mrs. Jennings began to relate all that she had heard and seen during her visit to the Middletons, dwelling particularly on the behaviour of Miss Steele towards Willoughby, and expressing her wonder at his not being more engaged in her favour. Marianne listened with apparent indifference, but her thoughts were busy in conjecturing what could be the meaning of Colonel Brandon's attentions, and why Willoughby should be so little affected by the preference of a woman who seemed to be making every effort to attract him. The dinner passed off without much conversation; Marianne was too much oppressed by the ideas which filled her mind to talk, and her mother, finding her so silent and pensive, was careful not to press her for explanations. After dinner, however, as they were sitting in the drawing-room, Mrs. Jennings, with a look of importance, said, "Marianne, my dear, I have something to tell you which I dare say will surprise you very much." Marianne looked up with some curiosity, and her mother continued, "You know, my dear, that I have been at the Middletons' a good deal these last days." Marianne bowed, and Mrs. Jennings went on, "Well, I was there last night, and I happened to be in the parlour when Miss Steele came in. She looked as white as a sheet, and I asked her what was the matter. At first, she would not tell me, but at last she burst out crying, and said, 'Oh, Mrs. Jennings, I am the most unhappy creature in the world!'"

She hoped fervently that his path would lead him to the happiness he deserved, even if it meant they would see less of each other. 'My dear fellow,' I should have said, 'consider what you are doing. You are making a most disgraceful connection, and such a one as your family are unanimous in disapproving.'
